results.title: ‘Infinity Pool’ and the Battle for an R Rating
results.abstract: The story of how an extreme horror movie with an orgy scene fought off an NC-17 label involves a film-board whisperer, minuscule cuts and talk of a new rating.

multimedia.caption: Ethan Noble specializes in helping films escape unwanted ratings.
multimedia.copyright: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

results.title: At Last Back at Sundance, Filled With Rocky Relationships and Glorious Writers
results.abstract: Dramas about couples (“Cat Person”) and families (“A Thousand and One”) tackle complex lives; documentaries on Judy Blume and Nikki Giovanni entertain.

multimedia.caption: Emilia Jones and Nicholas Braun in “Cat Person,” based on the New Yorker short story.
Emilia Jones and Nicholas Braun in “Cat Person,” based on the New Yorker short story.
Emilia Jones and Nicholas Braun in “Cat Person,” based on the New Yorker short story.

results.title: ‘A Thousand and One’ and Nikki Giovanni Documentary Win at Sundance Film Festival
results.abstract: Other prizes go to “Scrapper,” about a British girl and her estranged father, and “The Eternal Memory,” about a Chilean couple coping with Alzheimer’s.

multimedia.caption: Teyana Taylor and Aaron Kingsley Adetola in “A Thousand and One,” the U.S. Dramatic competition winner.

results.title: Mia Hansen-Love and the Hazy Line Where Real Life Ends and Art Begins
results.abstract: The French director translates her experiences into critically lauded dramas like “One Fine Morning,” about her father’s death and her own new love.

multimedia.caption: “I’ve never tried to hide that my films were partly inspired by experiences from my life,” Mia Hansen-Love said.
multimedia.copyright: Sam Hellmann for The New York Times

results.title: Once a Bullied Teen, Now the Movies’ Master Storyteller of Youth
results.abstract: At 31, Lukas Dhont already has two art-house hits to his name. The Belgian director’s latest film, “Close,” shows his skill at eliciting intense performances from young actors.

multimedia.copyright: Kevin Faingnaert for The New York Times
Kevin Faingnaert for The New York Times
Kevin Faingnaert for The New York Times

results.title: For the First Time Ever, I’m Optimistic About Women in the Movie World
results.abstract: It’s not just the volume and range of films centered on female characters. It’s also a shift in consciousness that has made feminist concerns mainstream.

results.title: Actress’s Path to Surprise Oscar Nomination Is Scrutinized
results.abstract: Andrea Riseborough got the nod for the little-seen “To Leslie.” The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is reviewing whether her A-list campaign violated rules.

results.title: Which Sundance Movies Could Follow ‘CODA’ to the Oscars?
results.abstract: Jonathan Majors in “Magazine Dreams” and Teyana Taylor in “A Thousand and One,” among others, could make the journey from Park City to the Dolby Theater.

results.title: Stream These 8 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in February
results.abstract: A handful of great titles are leaving the service for U.S. subscribers soon, including a bona fide comedy classic. See them while you can.

results.title: Gregory Allen Howard, Screenwriter of ‘Remember the Titans,’ Dies at 70
results.abstract: After the success of the movie, he established a brand for writing Hollywood movies about inspiring episodes in Black history.

multimedia.caption: Denzel Washington in “Remember The Titans.” Gregory Allen Howard wrote the script for the movie, which is based on a true story.

results.title: Sylvia Syms, Versatile British Actress, Is Dead at 89
results.abstract: In a career that began in the 1950s, she had roles that ranged from the lead in the movie “Teenage Bad Girl” to Margaret Thatcher and the Queen Mother.

multimedia.caption: The actress Sylvia Syms in 1957 en route to the Berlin Film Festival, where her movie “Woman in a Dressing Gown” was the official British entry.

results.title: The Responsibility of Watching
results.abstract: The video of Memphis police beating Tyre Nichols challenges public complacency — and complicity. What are our duties as citizens and as human beings?

multimedia.caption: An image from the body-cam video of the Memphis police beating Tyre Nichols. In viewing the footage, an ethical line separates witness from spectatorship.
multimedia.copyright: Memphis Police Department, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.abstract: This film, featuring a captivating performance from David Strathairn as the Polish resistance fighter Jan Karski, is a straightforward adaptation of the play of the same name.

results.title: ‘Cairo Conspiracy’ Review: There Are No Angels
results.abstract: The election of a grand imam is the backdrop for this tense drama of innocence and corruption set at an esteemed Islamic university.

results.title: ‘The Mission’ Review: A Substantial Service Undertaking
results.abstract: Teenagers from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints travel to Finland for missionary service in this documentary that offers limited insight.
des_facet: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)

multimedia.caption: In “The Mission,” we see teenagers pray and knock on Finns’ doors, “but before the camera, the companions default to reticence,” writes our critic.
In “The Mission,” we see teenagers pray and knock on Finns’ doors, “but before the camera, the companions default to reticence,” writes our critic.

results.abstract: Looking at the seasoned cast — Diane Keaton, Richard Gere, Susan Sarandon and William H. Macy — you might think you want to see this movie. Hold that thought.

results.title: Sundance, Once a Hotbed for Film Deals, Tries to Find Its Footing
results.abstract: The kind of independent movies that the festival showcases have struggled at the box office, spurring worries about what the market would be like this year.

results.title: Andrea Riseborough Can’t Believe She Was Nominated for an Oscar, Either
results.abstract: A social media campaign by some famous friends netted the star of “To Leslie,” a little-known microbudget indie, her first Oscar nomination.

results.title: Angela Bassett Nearly Missed the Announcement of Her Own Nomination
results.abstract: The sleepless actress had trouble with the television, but tuned in just as her category was being unveiled. “I’m glad I showed up on time,” she said.

multimedia.caption: Angela Bassett earned her second Oscar nomination on Tuesday, this time for “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever.”
